G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the events giving rise to the claims occurred in Springfield, Massachusetts, which is located in Hampden County.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 145 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence requires the showing of: (1) a duty owed by the Defendant to the Plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) causation; and (4) damages resulting from the breach. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 145 (2006).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 145 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly sets out the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim in Massachusetts, listing duty, breach, causation, and damages. That formulation matches the proposition stated, and it is given as a general statement of Massachusetts negligence law, not limited to the specific firearm facts of the case.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 145 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..raw_text: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 372 (2010) (property owners owe a duty of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm)
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed a duty to Plaintiff to act reasonably to avoid creating foreseeable risks of harm on the shared property, including the risks associated with storing a tall, unsecured extension ladder in a windy area near Plaintiff’s parking space. See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 372 (2010) (property owners owe a duty of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm); Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reiterates and applies the general Massachusetts premises-liability rule that property owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, focusing on foreseeable risks and the burden of avoiding them. Although the facts involve snow and ice rather than a ladder, the court’s articulation of duty is not limited to snow/ice: it states broadly that landowners must act as reasonable persons under all the circumstances to prevent foreseeable harm, which is the same principle invoked for storing an unsecured ladder on shared property.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.proposition: Defendant owed a duty to Plaintiff to act reasonably to avoid creating foreseeable risks of harm on the shared property, including the risks associated with storing a tall, unsecured extension ladder in a windy area near Plaintiff’s parking space. See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 372 (2010) (property owners owe a duty of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm); Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolishes the invitee/licensee distinction and adopts a general duty of reasonable care owed by property occupiers to lawful entrants, focusing on foreseeability rather than status. While the provided excerpt is only Kaplan’s concurrence and does not mention shared property or ladders, the case as a whole stands for the broader proposition that occupiers must act reasonably to avoid creating foreseeable risks of harm to those lawfully on the premises. Thus it can serve as authority for a general duty of reasonable care on property, though not for the specific ladder facts.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.relevant_excerpt: [From the main opinion, not shown in the excerpt provided:] “We hold that the obligation of reasonable care which we have described is owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors. The distinction between licensees and invitees should no longer be determinative of the degree of care owed.”

Caliri v. Condouris, 2006 WL 39152 (Mass.raw_text: Caliri v. Condouris, 2006 WL 39152 (Mass. App. Ct. 2006) (failure to address known property hazards establishes breach of duty)
Caliri v. Condouris, 2006 WL 39152 (Mass.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to properly secure the ladder despite Plaintiff’s repeated warnings about the foreseeable risk it posed. See Caliri v. Condouris, 2006 WL 39152 (Mass. App. Ct. 2006) (failure to address known property hazards establishes breach of duty).

Pessoni v. Sweet Assocs., Inc., 66 Mass..raw_text: Pessoni v. Sweet Assocs., Inc., 66 Mass. App. Ct. 360, 363 (2006) (reasonable property owners must recognize risks posed by foreseeable weather conditions)
Pessoni v. Sweet Assocs., Inc., 66 Mass..proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that leaning an extension ladder against a wooden fence in windy conditions created a foreseeable risk of harm to Plaintiff’s vehicle parked nearby. See Pessoni v. Sweet Assocs., Inc., 66 Mass. App. Ct. 360, 363 (2006) (reasonable property owners must recognize risks posed by foreseeable weather conditions).
Pessoni v. Sweet Assocs., Inc., 66 Mass..support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a criminal case about execution of a search warrant, knock-and-announce, expectation of privacy, and chain of custody. It does not involve premises liability, property owner duties, weather conditions, or foreseeability of harm from wind or objects like ladders and fences. Therefore, it does not establish or discuss any rule that reasonable property owners must recognize risks posed by foreseeable weather conditions, and it cannot support the cited negligence proposition.
Pessoni v. Sweet Assocs., Inc., 66 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "The requirement that police ‘knock and announce’ their presence and purpose prior to the execution of a search warrant ‘has long been part of our common law.’ Commonwealth v. Macias, 429 Mass. 698, 700 (1999). ... The rule requiring law enforcement officials to knock and announce themselves when executing a warrant remains a principle of common law rather than a constitutional mandate."

Leavitt v. Brockton Hospital, Inc., 454.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hospital, Inc., 454 Mass. 37, 40 (2009) (proximate cause exists where harm is a foreseeable result of the defendant’s conduct).
Leavitt v. Brockton Hospital, Inc., 454.proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was the direct and proximate cause of the damages Plaintiff sustained when the unsecured ladder fell onto her vehicle. See Leavitt v. Brockton Hospital, Inc., 454 Mass. 37, 40 (2009) (proximate cause exists where harm is a foreseeable result of the defendant’s conduct).
Leavitt v. Brockton Hospital, Inc., 454.support_reasoning: The proposition uses Leavitt as generic authority that proximate cause exists where harm is a foreseeable result of the defendant’s conduct and then applies that to an unsecured ladder falling on a vehicle. Leavitt does discuss proximate cause in terms of foreseeability, but it ultimately holds that the plaintiff’s injury was *not* within the scope of foreseeable risk and thus that proximate cause was lacking. The case therefore does not support a claim that proximate cause exists in the ladder scenario; at most it provides a general foreseeability standard, which in Leavitt cut against finding proximate cause.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hospital, Inc., 454.relevant_excerpt: “Liability for conduct obtains only where the conduct is both a cause in fact of the injury and where the resulting injury is within the scope of the foreseeable risk arising from the negligent conduct. See id. at § 29, at 575; Kent v. Commonwealth, supra at 320 (plaintiff must show cause in fact and that injury was ‘foreseeable result’ of conduct); Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., supra (no causation where ‘harm which occurred was not within the scope of foreseeable risk to the victim’).”

Gorfinkle v. U.S. Carpet Cleaning, Inc.,.raw_text: Gorfinkle v. U.S. Carpet Cleaning, Inc., 2014 WL 7496563 (Mass. App. Ct. 2014) (damages in negligence include reasonable costs directly resulting from defendant’s actions).
Gorfinkle v. U.S. Carpet Cleaning, Inc.,.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff incurred financial losses, including out-of-pocket expenses to repair her vehicle and costs for a rental car during the repair period. See Gorfinkle v. U.S. Carpet Cleaning, Inc., 2014 WL 7496563 (Mass. App. Ct. 2014) (damages in negligence include reasonable costs directly resulting from defendant’s actions).

P. 11.proposition: I, Jessica Parker, certify that I have read the above Complaint and that to the best of my knowledge, information, and belief formed after reasonable inquiry, the Complaint is well-grounded in fact, is warranted by existing law or a good faith argument for the extension, modification, or reversal of existing law, and is not interposed for any improper purpose.
